title: Chapter 145
content: # Chapter 145 Grid pulled up his inventory, fingers trembling as he examined the loot from the awakened guardian. > **[Blue Orichalcum]** > > A mineral born from moonlight and the Guardian of the Forest's essence. Impervious to the Guardian's magic, it possesses unmatched hardness and tensile strength among known minerals. > > Lightweight. Defensive properties amplify in darkness. > > *Requires Advanced Blacksmith Mastery to smelt.* > > **Weight:** 3 > **[Purple Orichalcum]** > > Obtainable only when the Guardian awakens beneath twin full moons. > > Channels unique magic that enhances attack power and spell potency. Structurally fragile compared to blue orichalcum. > > Unsuitable for armor or weapons. Ideal for accessory crafting. > > *Requires Master-level Blacksmith skill to smelt.* > > **Weight:** 1 > **[Amethyst Shield]** > > **Rating:** Epic > **Durability:** 200/200 > **Defense:** 200 > **Magic Resistance:** 200 > > A shield that shifts between purple, crimson, and obsidian depending on the viewing angle. Symbolic regalia awarded exclusively to the Captain of the Red Knights. > > Lost three years ago when Piaro—framed as a traitor by Asmophel—fled to the Eternal Kingdom. > > The Third Prince of the Saharan Empire seeks this shield. > > **User Restriction:** Red Knights Captain > **Weight:** 350 > > *[No hidden functions detected.]* Grid's jaw clenched. *Fourteen. Exactly fourteen blue orichalcum.* His hands balled into fists. Failure required fifteen pieces. Fifteen. Someone, something in this goddamn game was mocking him. *One short. One fucking piece short.* His breath came faster. *Would've been better to get five or six. Not fourteen. Not one away from what I need.* He pressed his palm against his forehead. If he hadn't sweet-talked Administrator Valdi months ago, if he hadn't squeezed three pieces out of that transaction... *I'd be screwed. Completely screwed.* "It's a miracle," he muttered, then louder, forcing his voice steady. "An enormous miracle." He switched to the purple orichalcum before his anxiety spiraled further. Accessories. He had two: Doran's Ring—proven, reliable, lifesaving. The other... > **[Ring of Pledge]** > > **Rating:** Unique > > A token of eternal love. > > Grants the **Happy** status when near your spouse: **+8%** Movement Speed, **+30** to all stats. > > *Status varies by spouse's affection level: Happy, Joyful, Content, Neutral, Displeased, Depressed, Resentful.* > > Spending an intimate night with your spouse while wearing this ring increases **all skill experience by 10%**. > *Intimate encounters available once per month.* > > While worn, affinity gains with NPCs of the opposite sex (excluding spouse) are severely reduced. > > If your spouse catches you not wearing this ring, **affinity drops by 90%** and pregnancy chance decreases dramatically. > > **Weight:** 0.1 Grid stared at the description. The benefits only worked around Irene. The skill boost capped at once monthly. Worse, it actively sabotaged building relationships with female NPCs. *I don't need to wear this. Not constantly.* But his hand moved to the ring, confirming its presence. *Then again...* If Irene discovered him without it, her affection would plummet ninety percent. He wasn't lucky. Even with his recent fortune, one unlucky moment... *Best not risk it.* The pregnancy mechanic caught his attention. Satisfy simulated that far? *Raising a kid. Teaching them. Discovering talents.* The concept held appeal. Then reality reasserted itself. Over a decade to raise one child. With the gender ratio in Satisfy skewing so heavily male, the "second generation system" seemed more gimmick than feature. "Necklace." He nodded to himself. "Purple orichalcum necklace." Multiple rings were possible. Only one necklace. The math was simple. Necklaces carried better stats. "I'll need a jeweler." Khan would know someone reputable. His gaze shifted to the Amethyst Shield. The quest item. His pulse quickened again. Piaro's words from Kesan Canyon echoed in his memory. *Asmophel. The betrayer. The man who framed me.* Asmophel served in the Saharan Empire. *Someday,* Grid told himself. *When I deliver this shield to the Third Prince, I'll settle that score for Piaro.* The Empire was half a continent away. Not an immediate problem. He tucked the shield into a remote corner of his inventory, then looked up as footsteps approached. "You okay?" Romeo's voice cracked with worry. The soldiers clustered behind him, eyes wide. They'd watched Grid take the awakened guardian's final flash attack head-on. None had expected him to survive. Grid waved dismissively. "I told you. The gods blessed me. I don't die that easily." He gripped Romeo's shoulder, his expression darkening. "Deck, though... Damn shame. I'm sorry. Should've protected him better." The words tasted sincere. Khan had taught him blacksmiths were people. Irene had shown him NPCs bled the same as users. Deck had been young, talented, promising. Now he was data fragments scattered across some server. Romeo's eyes glistened. "He saved half a dozen men on the march here. We won't forget." The soldiers bowed their heads in silent agreement. A screech split the night sky. "The hell—?" "Gargoyle?!" Massive wings beat against the darkness. Grid squinted upward. The silhouette was too large, too heavy for a gargoyle. Moonlight painted scales the color of dried blood. *Drake.* Four meters of apex predator. Rare beyond measure. A wyvern looked like a pigeon next to this thing. Griffons and gargoyles? Prey species. The drake descended, and Grid's jaw actually dropped. "My Liege." The rider dismounted with a theatrical flourish. "Have you been well in the meantime?" "Huroi." Grid's surprise lasted exactly two seconds. Then his eyes narrowed, analyzing. *Combat power: 10,000. Two thousand more than Romeo.* Level 200-plus. As an orator. A non-combat class. *The second class really transformed him.* "You've grown strong," Grid said. Huroi clasped his hands together. "All thanks to My Liege's—" "Good. You can repay me by serving under me properly now." "...Pardon?" They hadn't spoken in four, maybe five months game-time. Huroi had stories. The drake acquisition alone was an epic. He'd planned to share adventures, ask about Grid's marriage to nobility, reconnect like— "Hunt frostlight orcs." Grid's tone brooked no argument. "I need sylphid scales. Minimum twenty-eight." "Why would I—" "Low drop rate, I know. Ten days should cover it if you're efficient." Huroi's mouth worked silently. Only a hundred users worldwide controlled drakes. Peak aerial mobility. Devastating combat potential. And Grid wanted him to... "Farm mobs. For crafting materials." "The scales are for an invisibility cloak," Grid explained, as if this justified everything. "Hooded Zip-Up. Needs twenty to craft. I tried grinding them myself before I got Pagma's Swordsmanship. Gave up after twelve." He gestured at the drake like it was a mining pick. "Now you're here. I'll make two: one for me, one to auction. We'll split the profit." *No,* Huroi thought. *You'll take seventy percent and call it generosity.* But then the memories surfaced. Winston's dungeon. Two hundred hours of darkness and despair. Grid's hand extended through the bars, offering salvation. The frostlight orc chief. Stunned, defenseless, skull about to cave in. Grid's body shielding him from the deathblow. *He saved me. Twice.* "I'll leave immediately," Huroi said. A ranker couldn't afford ten days in one hunting ground. His leveling would stagnate. His ranking would slip. But debts were debts. He turned toward the drake. "Wait." Grid pointed at Romeo and the soldiers. "Walk." "...What?" "If you fly, they can't follow. Take them along. Train them while you hunt." Huroi stared. Ground travel would double the time investment. Babysitting soldiers would triple the tedium. "You don't want to?" Grid's voice dropped half an octave. "...No, My Liege." The descendants of the Blue Wolf honored their oaths. Huroi bowed stiffly, then trudged toward the soldiers. Grid watched them depart, humming tunelessly. *Perfect timing,* he thought. *I wanted those scales, but grinding them myself was idiotic. Too inefficient.* Guilt tugged at his conscience. Faint. Barely perceptible. *I'll craft him something nice later. Stop whining, conscience.* He'd cleared his debt. Six hundred million won of crushing pressure, gone. The act had loosened something in his personality. Made him fractionally less selfish. Fractionally. *First things first.* His body lifted off the ground, Braham's Boots humming with power. *Time to make Failure.* The flight toward Khan's smithy was fast, though nowhere near drake-speed. * * * Hours later, the Grey Forest stood silent. A figure materialized in the clearing where blood still stained the moss. "Impossible." The man surveyed the destruction with narrowed eyes. "The Tzedakah Guild couldn't drop an awakened guardian. Not this one." Someone from the top five unified rankings had gotten here first. "Wasted trip." He spat into the dirt. "Four-month respawn timer. I can't camp this location indefinitely." The ID above his head flickered in the moonlight as he vanished into shadow. **Agnus.** --- **Glossary of Common Korean Terms:** OG: Glossary Link **Current Schedule:** 20 chapters a week *Check out my Patreon for early access to unedited chapters and support goals for bonus releases. Early access updates after daily chapter completion.*
